source.raw_text:
The V-Up is a full-body core exercise primarily targeting the rectus abdominis, obliques, and hip flexors, while also engaging legs (hamstrings, quads, glutes) and shoulders for stabilization, requiring simultaneous lifting of the torso and legs into a 'V' shape from a flat starting position, demanding significant core strength and coordination for controlled movement. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary: Rectus Abdominis (the "six-pack" muscles). 
• Secondary: Obliques, Transverse Abdominis (deeper core), Hip Flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris). 
• Stabilizers: Glutes, Hamstrings, Quadriceps, Shoulders (Deltoids), Upper Back (Erector Spinae). [3, 4]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: Lie flat on your back, arms extended overhead, legs straight, forming a line with your body. 
2. Concentric (Lifting) Phase: Exhale as you simultaneously lift your legs and torso off the floor, keeping your legs relatively straight, crunching your abs to bring your hands towards your feet (or shins) to form a 'V' shape. 
3. Peak Contraction: Squeeze your abs at the top, keeping your back straight to avoid arching. 
4. Eccentric (Lowering) Phase: Inhale as you slowly and controlled lower your torso and legs back to the starting position, maintaining core tension. [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Key Technique Points 

• Coordination: This is a full-body movement requiring simultaneous lift. 
• Control: Avoid using momentum; focus on slow, controlled movements to maximize core engagement. 
• Breathing: Exhale on exertion (lifting), inhale on return (lowering). 
• Progression: Start with variations like reverse crunches or bent-knee leg raises to build strength before attempting full V-ups. [5, 6, 7, 8]  

**Citations:**
